verses.text: Whoever fears the Lord will do what is right, and those who are devoted to Him will find favor.
verses.comment: The connection between fearing God and living righteously is foundational in the wisdom literature. It echoes the call throughout Scripture to seek God wholeheartedly (see Proverbs 9:10).

verses.text: She will meet him like a mother, and accept him as a young bride.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified here, drawing from earlier traditions (see Proverbs 8). The maternal imagery implies care, intimacy, and instruction, which establishes a familial bond between Wisdom and the faithful.

verses.text: She will feed him with the bread of understanding, and give him the water of wisdom to drink.
verses.comment: Bread and water symbolize sustenance. There is a resonance here with the New Testament, where Christ refers to Himself as the true bread and living water (see John 6:35; John 4:14), presenting Wisdom as fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: He will lean on her and not fall; he will trust in her and not be put to shame.
verses.comment: Trust in divine wisdom guarantees stability. Compare the trust in Wisdom here with faith in Christ, which protects and upholds the believer (Matthew 7:24-25).

verses.text: She will lift him high above his neighbors, and in the midst of the assembly she will open his mouth.
verses.comment: Being exalted and given words to speak is reminiscent of the Spirit prompting believers to speak in assemblies (see Luke 12:12), suggesting a divine gift entrusted to those rooted in Wisdom.

verses.text: He will find joy and a crown of gladness, and will inherit an everlasting name.
verses.comment: A crown often indicates reward for faithfulness (see 2 Timothy 4:8). The inheritance of an 'everlasting name' hints at the enduring honor and life promised to those who follow the Lord.

verses.text: But the foolish will not find her, and sinners will not see her.
verses.comment: The inability of the sinner to perceive Wisdom is echoed in the New Testament (see 1 Corinthians 2:14). Purity of heart is crucial for recognizing divine truth.

verses.text: For she is far from pride, and liars will never think of her.
verses.comment: Humility is a precondition for finding Wisdom. This is consistent with the biblical teaching that God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble (James 4:6).

verses.text: Praise is unseemly in the mouth of a sinner, for it was not sent from the Lord.
verses.comment: True worship flows from a sincere heart. The empty praise or religious acts of those in sin are not pleasing to God, hinting at the importance of a life consistent with worship.

verses.text: For praise is spoken in wisdom, and the Lord Himself leads it.
verses.comment: True worship is both directed and inspired by God. This points toward the necessity of both Spirit and truth in worship (John 4:24), as the Lord desires praise that arises from wisdom.

verses.text: Do not say, "It was the Lord who made me stray," for He does not do what He hates.
verses.comment: Affirming God's holiness and human freedom, this echoes James 1:13. God cannot be blamed for sin; He only wills the good.

verses.text: Do not say, "It was He who led me astray," for He has no need of a sinner.
verses.comment: God does not tempt people to do evil, a doctrine reaffirmed in both covenants. This upholds the justice and goodness of God.

verses.text: The Lord hates every abomination, and those who fear Him will not love such things.
verses.comment: Believers are called to love what God loves and hate what He hates. This is an important theme in spiritual formation.

verses.text: He Himself made man in the beginning, and left him in the hand of his own counsel.
verses.comment: Human beings are created with free will. The balance between God’s sovereignty and human freedom is structurally significant to the biblical tradition.

verses.text: He added His commandments and precepts: if you will, you can keep them; to act faithfully is within your power.
verses.comment: The text affirms both divine command and human responsibility. The possibility of keeping the commandments points to the necessity of grace, seen more fully in the New Testament (John 15:5).

verses.text: He has set before you fire and water; stretch out your hand to whichever you choose.
verses.comment: The symbolism of fire and water represents the choice between life and death, blessing and curse. True freedom is choosing the good.

verses.text: Before each person are life and death, and whichever one he chooses will be given to him.
verses.comment: Echoing Deuteronomy, this verse stresses personal accountability. Eternal consequences depend on our response to God’s gifts.

verses.text: For great is the wisdom of the Lord; He is mighty in power, and sees all things.
verses.comment: God's omniscience and omnipotence guarantee justice and provide a basis for trust in His laws and providence.

verses.text: His eyes are on those who fear Him, and He knows every work people do.
verses.comment: The Lord’s watchful care over the righteous motivates them to persevere in good works. This continued theme finds fulfillment in Christ’s teachings on the Father’s care (Matthew 6:4, 18).

verses.text: He has not commanded anyone to be wicked, nor has He given anyone permission to sin.
verses.comment: Concludes the chapter’s reflection on free will: God is not the author of evil. This clarifies that human choice is real and morally significant, consistent with the larger biblical narrative stressing the need for grace, repentance, and faithfulness to God’s commands.
